title-group.article-title: Postoperative Second Metatarsal Fractures Associated With Suture-Button Implant in Hallux Valgus Surgery

article-meta.aff: 1Broward Orthopedic Specialists, Fort Lauderdale, Florida, USA
2New York University Hospital for Joint Diseases, New York, New York, USA

author-notes.corresp: Justin M. Weatherall, Broward Orthopedic Specialists, P.A., 5301 N. Dixie Hwy, Suite 203, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33334 Email: justinweatherallmd@gmail.com

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The purpose of this study was to perform a retrospective review of a nonosteotomy technique for the reduction of the intermetatarsal (IM) angle in hallux valgus (HV) surgery using a modified nonabsorbable suture-button implant previously described for ankle syndesmotic injuries and to report on the outcomes and complications associated with this technique.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: A retrospective review was performed of consecutive patients with a minimum follow-up of 1 year. Twenty-five patients, a total of 25 feet, were identified with a mean follow-up of 22.5 months. The mean age was 60 years. The pre- and postoperative HV and IM angles were compared. Each postoperative radiograph was assessed for loss of correction, implant failure, and second metatarsal (MT) stress fracture. The postoperative hallux American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society (AOFAS) scores were obtained at the patient’s final follow-up visit. Statistics were performed using the paired Student t test with the P value set at .05 to determine statistical differences.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The preoperative mean IM and HV angles were 15.1 and 30.5 degrees, respectively. The postoperative mean IM and HV angles were 8.2 and 10.2 degrees, respectively. The reductions in the IM and HV angles were statistically significant (P < .05). The average postoperative AOFAS hallux score was 85. Two patients developed hallux varus (8%). Eight patients (32%) developed second metatarsal stress fractures. One patient (4%) with a second metatarsal stress fracture had a failure of the implant that required implant removal. The remaining stress fractures healed uneventfully.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Suture-button fixation in hallux valgus achieved a satisfactory reduction in the first–second intermetatarsal angle compared with first metatarsal osteotomies but was associated with a high rate of second metatarsal stress fractures.

sec.title: Level of Evidence:
sec.p: Level IV, retrospective case series.

body.p: Many options for surgical treatment of hallux valgus currently exist and depend on patient demands, radiographic measures, and surgeon training.6,7 Distal or proximal first metatarsal osteotomies or first tarsometatarsal fusions with or without a distal soft tissue release are currently used in the treatment of most hallux valgus deformities.2,16,19,20,24 Complications associated with these osteotomies include malunion, nonunion, osteonecrosis of the metatarsal head, metatarsal shortening, transfer metatarsalgia, displacement, and technical difficulty associated with the osteotomy.10,11,15,18,21,23,25,26,29,36

Interosseous suture and button devices such as the TightRope and Mini TightRope (Arthrex, Naples, FL) have multiple applications described in the literature such as ankle syndesmotic fixation associated with ankle fractures, distal radioulnar joint disruptions, acromioclavicular joint separations, Lisfranc injuries, hallux varus correction, and reduction of the first-second intermetatarsal angle in hallux valgus.4,5,9,12,27,34,38 Complications associated with these devices used in ankle syndesmotic fixation include loss of reduction and soft tissue irritation with granuloma formation.30,35 A few case reports have been published in the literature describing second metatarsal fractures associated with interosseous suture and button fixation as an alternative to first metatarsal osteotomy for correction of the first–second intermetatarsal angle.14,17

The purpose of this study was to perform a retrospective review of a nonosteotomy technique for the reduction of the intermetatarsal angle in hallux valgus surgery using a modified nonabsorbable suture-button implant previously described for ankle syndesmotic injuries and to report on the outcomes and complications associated with this technique.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: After institutional review board approval, a retrospective review of consecutive patients who underwent a nonosteotomy technique for intermetatarsal angle reduction in adults with hallux valgus using a nonabsorbable suture-button implant was performed between 2006 and 2007. The minimum follow-up was 1 year. Inclusion criteria include hallux valgus angles greater than or equal to 12 degrees, as well as nonarthritic first metatarsophalangeal joint and tarsometatarsal joints, that failed nonoperative management. Patients were followed up at regular intervals postoperatively. Radiographs were performed preoperatively, intraoperatively, and at each visit starting with the 3-month postoperative visit.

Twenty-five consecutive patients and a total of 25 feet were identified and underwent the described procedure. The average follow up was 22.5 (range, 17-26) months. All of the patients in the study were females. The average age was 60 (range, 42-78) years (Table 1). Eighteen of 25 surgeries included a distal soft tissue procedure if the hallux valgus was not passively correctable preoperatively. Twelve other procedures were performed on the lesser toes. Those procedures included isolated hammertoes in 2 patients, fifth metatarsal osteotomies in 3 patients, second metatarsal distal osteotomies in 2 patients, second metatarsal condylectomy in 1 patient, and a combined second distal metatarsal osteotomy and hammertoe correction in toes 2 and 3.

Hallux valgus and intermetatarsal angles were measured preoperatively and were measured again on the radiographs taken at the patient’s final follow-up appointment. The pre- and postoperative hallux valgus and intermetatarsal angles were compared. Each postoperative radiograph was assessed for loss of correction, implant failure, and second metatarsal stress reaction or fracture. The postoperative hallux American Orthopaedic Foot & Ankle Society (AOFAS) scores were obtained at the patient’s final follow-up visit. Statistics were performed using the paired Student t test with the P value set at .05, to determine statistical differences.

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: In almost all the surgeries, a distal soft tissue procedure was performed that included release of the adductor tendon from the base of the proximal phalanx and from the fibular sesamoid, release of the intermetatarsal ligament in the first webspace, and release of the lateral capsule of the first metatarsophalangeal joint. Next, a standard medial incision was made to approach the first metatarsal. The capsule was identified, and an L-shaped incision was made starting dorsally and turning plantarward 90 degrees at the level of the joint. The medial eminence was then removed with a sagittal saw. An elevator was used to expose the distal aspect of the diaphysis of the second metatarsal and the lateral aspect of the first metatarsal, and a retractor was then placed around the lateral border of the second metatarsal. The nonabsorbable suture-button implant used was the Mini TightRope. The 1.2-mm guide wire was inserted from medial to lateral across the first metatarsal starting just proximal to the medial eminence, and the wire was aimed at a point approximately 2 to 5 mm proximal to the neck of the second metatarsal aiming for the center of the metatarsal shaft. Next, a tunnel was drilled with the 2.7-mm cannulated drill bit. The 1.6-mm guide pin with the pull-through suture with the Tightrope attached was passed through the drill holes from lateral to medial. The oblong button of the Tightrope device was passed first through the second metatarsal to the medial side of the first metatarsal and flipped. The first and second metatarsals were clamped together to hold the appropriate intermetatarsal angle, and the trailing round button was tightened down to the lateral aspect of the second metatarsal shaft by applying gradual tension on the 2 suture strands. Two or three half-hitches were tied on top of the round button to secure the device. Last, a medial capsule closure was performed with the goal of achieving the desired hallux valgus angle. Postoperatively, the patients were placed in a CAM boot with instructions to remain non–weight bearing for the first 2 weeks, and then the patient was allowed bear weight as tolerated in the walker boot for 4 more weeks. After 6 weeks, the patient was transitioned to a shoe.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The preoperative intermetatarsal and hallux valgus angles were 15.1 degrees (range, 12-20 degrees) and 30.5 degrees (range, 24-48 degrees), respectively. The postoperative intermetatarsal and hallux valgus angles were 8.2 degrees (range, 6-11 degrees) and 10.2 degrees (range, 10-22 degrees), respectively. The reductions in the intermetatarsal angle and the hallux valgus angle were statistically significant (P < .05) compared with their preoperative values. The mean postoperative AOFAS Hallux score was 85 points (range, 34-100 points) (Table 2).

tr.td: Combined distal soft tissue procedures, n
Combined procedures on lesser toes, n

sec.p: Postoperatively, there was no change in the length of the first metatarsal. No arthrosis of the tarsometatarsal joints was noted on follow-up radiographs. Two patients out of 25 (8%) had radiographic hallux varus, of which 1 was clinically noticeable (10 degrees of varus), but neither was symptomatic. The 2 patients who developed hallux varus both had distal soft tissue releases. The most common complication was a stress fracture in the second metatarsal around the drill hole used to pass the suture-button (Figure 1 and 2). Eight patients out of 25 (32%) developed second metatarsal stress fractures. Almost all fractures occurred around 10 to 12 weeks postoperatively. All patients with a stress fracture were treated with a CAM walker. One patient out of 25 (4%) with a second metatarsal stress fracture had a failure of the implant that required implant removal, and at the time of implant removal a distal chevron osteotomy was performed. The remaining stress fractures healed uneventfully with no dorsal tilt of the metatarsal head (Figure 3). One patient had a subsequent surgery to have the Tightrope removed by a different surgeon (Table 3). The mean AOFAS score of the 8 patients with a second metatarsal stress fracture was 89 (range, 80-100), and the mean postoperative hallux valgus and intermetatarsal angles were 10.5 degrees (range, 8-12 degrees) and 9 degrees (range, 7-11 degrees), respectively.

caption.p: (A) Implant intact prior to the second metatarsal stress fracture. (B) Subsequent fracture and early callus formation.
(A) Two implants intact across the first and second metatarsals. (B) Fracture of the second metatarsal at the most distal implant.

Subsequent healed stress fractures. (A) Healed second metatarsal stress fracture with a severe valgus malunion. (B) The most common appearance of the healed stress fracture with minimal deformity of the fracture site and an intact implant.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The TightRope has been used successfully in multiple surgical applications such as ankle syndesmotic fixation in cases of syndesmotic disruption associated with ankle fractures and Lisfranc fractures.4,5 Recently, a few publications have looked at the TightRope specifically as an alternative to first metatarsal osteotomy for the reduction of first–second intermetatarsal angle in the treatment of hallux valgus.13,14,17,27 To our knowledge, no study of this size has been published to date that has shown a possible association of metatarsal stress fractures when using the TightRope for the reduction of the first-second intermetatarsal angle.

Overall, the TightRope produces comparable reductions in the first–second intermetatarsal angle compared with first metatarsal osteotomies.1,3,22,32 Adam et al1 published their outcomes for 29 patients who underwent scarf first metatarsal osteotomies; the investigators reported that hallux valgus angle improved from 34.6 to 14.9 degrees and the intermetatarsal angle improved from 15.8 degrees to 7.2 degrees.1 Trnka et al32 found a reduction in the mean intermetatarsal angle from 17 to 8 degrees in their series of 111 feet that underwent a Ludloff osteotomy for hallux valgus. Coetzee et al3 published a prospective cohort study in 105 feet that underwent a Lapidus first tarsometatarsal fusion for hallux valgus, and the authors reported that the first–second intermetatarsal angle decreased from 18 degrees to 8.2 degrees and the hallux valgus angle decreased from 37 degrees to 16 degrees. In our study we found that the mean hallux valgus angle decreased from 30.5 degrees to 10.2 degrees and the intermetatarsal angle decreased from 15.1 degrees to 8.2 degrees.

Most patients subjectively reported excellent outcomes after this procedure. In our study, the average postoperative hallux AOFAS score was 85 points. All of the patients except 1 reported scores of 82 and higher. The 1 patient who reported a score of 68 did not have a stress reaction or fracture but underwent second and third hammertoe corrections with a second Weil osteotomy. Our report does not include average preoperative AOFAS scores, but in a 2011 study Adam et al1 reported a mean preoperative AOFAS score of 61.5 (range, 34-76) in patients with an average age of 55 years.1 The average age of the patients in our study was 60 years.

One of the principle advantages of using the TightRope is the lack of metatarsal shortening that occurs with first metatarsal osteotomies. Theoretically this should reduce the incidence of transfer lesions to the second metatarsal head. Multiples studies have been published demonstrating that some first metatarsal osteotomies have the potential to cause transfer metatarsalgia.15,21,23,36 By not shortening the first metatarsal, it may obviate the need to perform a Weil shortening osteotomy in cases of long second or third rays.

Two (8%) of the 25 patients in our series had radiographic hallux varus with only 1 having clinically significant hallux varus of 10 degrees. Both patients who developed hallux varus also had a concomitant distal soft tissue release as part of their bunion correction. Trnka et al33 reported a 19.2% rate of iatrogenic hallux varus after hallux valgus surgery. The authors reported an average of 10.1 degrees of hallux varus deformity, but 11 of the 16 patients reported excellent results. The investigators found that only patients with extreme deformity were unsatisfied or needed more surgery.33 Thordarson et al31 found a rate of hallux varus of 17% in their retrospective series of proximal metatarsal osteotomies.

The most concerning outcome of our study was the high rate of metatarsal stress fractures (32%) in the second metatarsal after this procedure. Despite having the complication of a second metatarsal stress fracture, the patients in this group reported a mean AOFAS score of 89 and had mean postoperative hallux valgus and intermetatarsal angles of 10.5 and 9 degrees, respectively. These numbers are very similar to the group as a whole. The second metatarsal may become biomechanically weaker by this procedure since it requires a 2.7-mm hole to be drilled transversely across the second metatarsal shaft. The risk of second metatarsal stress fracture may be increased by surgeon error if multiple drill holes are made or the drill hole is not made in the center of the bone. A few case reports of second metatarsal stress fractures have been reported in the literature associated with this technique.14,17 Second metatarsal stress fractures have been reported to occur also after Keller arthroplasty for bunion correction.8,37 Sammarco et al28 published a series of 88 consecutive patients who underwent a proximal chevron osteotomy; 2 of the 88 patients developed a second metatarsal stress fracture. All of the stress fractures in our study occurred at approximately 10 to 12 weeks postoperatively. The stress fractures were all treated by placing the patient in a CAM walker for 4 to 6 weeks, and all of the stress fractures healed with this treatment. The patient who had a stress fracture where the implant failed subsequently underwent removal of hardware and distal chevron osteotomy to treat the recurrent bunion. There were no other implant failures in the remaining 7 fractures, and no patient complained of metatarsalgia despite the fractures.

Based on the results of our study, we changed our postoperative management from a postoperative shoe to a CAM walker for the first month postoperatively. A technical advantage of making an incision over the second metatarsal to perform a Weil osteotomy or a distal soft tissue procedure is the ability to directly visualize the second metatarsal shaft when drilling the hole for the device, which may theoretically reduce the risk of second metatarsal stress reaction or fracture by placing the drill hole in the ideal location on the bone.

Limitations of our study include its retrospective nature, short follow-up, lack of a control group, small sample size, and lack of preoperative AOFAS scores. To more definitively address the risk of injury to the second metatarsal, a prospective study with longer follow-up is necessary. Also, the risk of injury to the second metatarsal may be mitigated by the use of a CAM boot for the first month postoperatively instead of a postoperative shoe. In December 2008, the operative technique for the mini TightRope was changed from a 2.7-mm drill hole through the second metatarsal to a 1.1-mm drill hole. The change in technique to smaller drill bit may substantially decrease or eliminate the risk of second metatarsal stress fracture. Since we changed to the smaller drill bit we have not had any fractures of the second metatarsal. If the risk of second metatarsal injury can be addressed, then this technique may offer an acceptable alternative to first metatarsal osteotomies for patients with a large first-second intermetatarsal angle, especially in revision cases where prior osteotomies have been performed in the shaft of the first metatarsal.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Suture-button fixation inserted with a 2.7-mm drill bit in hallux valgus achieved a satisfactory reduction in the first–second intermetatarsal angle compared with first metatarsal osteotomies but is associated with a high rate of second metatarsal stress fractures. The patients who sustained a second metatarsal stress fracture reported excellent outcomes without loss of the correction of the hallux valgus and intermetatarsal angles.

fn.label: Editor’s Note
fn.p: The authors are to be congratulated for honest reporting of their high rate of stress fractures. Although the stress fractures apparently healed uneventfully, I would not be surprised if some patients eventually develop transfer metatarsalgia due to dorsal drift at the second metatarsal fracture site. Perhaps their use of a smaller implant/drill bit will resolve this problem.
